item.title: Hamburg Journal: As German Church Becomes Mosque, Neighbors Start to Shed Unease
item.description: The building, which was deconsecrated in 2002, will be used by a mosque whose 2,000 congregants have been meeting since 1993 in a parking garage.
item.dc:creator: JESSE COBURN
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Daniel Abdin, director of the Islamic Center Al Nour in Hamburg, Germany. This former church is being converted into a mosque to accommodate Al Nour's 2,000 congregants, who come from more than 30 countries.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ma Xue on Why China Has Embraced Korean TV
item.description: Ms. Ma, a culture critic, TV host and producer, helps companies create television shows for the Chinese market.
item.category: My Love From Another Star (TV Program)
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: Ma Xue helps companies create television shows for the Chinese market.

item.title: Boko Haram Helped by U.S. Policies, Nigeria President Says
item.description: Two days after meeting with President Obama, President Muhammadu Buhari said the refusal to arm Nigerian forces made it harder to fight the militants.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria said on Wednesday that his country’s security forces were “largely impotent” in their fight against Boko Haram, and that an American law was partly to blame.

item.title: Rift Widens in Tunisia as Government Cracks Down on Mosques
item.description: Some fear that restrictions, enforced after the massacre of 38 tourists last month, signal a return to the authoritarian ways of the former dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Tunisians arrived at the El-Abidine mosque, on the outskirts of the capital, Tunis, to attend Eid al-Fitr prayers last week.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Police Vanquish Foreigners Clad as Spartans
item.description: The men had assembled as a promotional activity for an organic salad delivery service when the police showed up after complaints of “disturbing street order,” local media reported.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: U Aung Thaung, Burmese Politician Accused of Abuses, Dies at 74
item.description: He was the industry minister from 1997 to 2011, a position that he was said to have manipulated to financially benefit himself, his family and aides.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Burmese politician U Aung Thaung at a ceremony in Myanmar's capital, Naypyidaw, in 2011.

item.title: Israeli Forces Shoot and Kill Palestinian During West Bank Raid
item.description: Falah Abu Marya, 53, was shot in the chest as he threw objects at soldiers from a balcony during an operation in Beit Ommar, an Israeli rights group said.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Relatives mourned during the funeral of Falah Abu Marya, who was shot and killed by Israeli troops on Thursday in the West Bank village of Beit Ommar.

item.title: A Bangladeshi Town in Human Trafficking’s Grip
item.description: Fishermen, shopkeepers and policemen were all drawn in, as participants or observers, to a multimillion-dollar people smuggling business.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Testing the U.S.-Israel Bond
item.description: What sort of support does Israel deserve to expect from Americans, including Jewish Americans?
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Personalities Clashing Over How to Handle New Greek Bailout
item.description: Nearly all agree that Greece’s debt is unsustainably high, but figuring out how to grapple with it has unleashed a volatile mix of politics, economics, history and even morality.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras at a session of Parliament in Athens last week.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A ‘Third Way’ to Fight Climate Change
item.description: Technologies to capture carbon dioxide and store it or use it to create things we can use need will become a major focus.
item.dc:creator: TIM FLANNERY

item.title: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter Makes Unannounced Visit to Iraq
item.description: Mr. Carter arrived as American and Iraqi officials finished plans for an assault to retake Ramadi, a pivotal city west of Baghdad, from the Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter on his way to Jordan from Saudi Arabia on Wednesday. He made an unannounced visit to Iraq on Thursday.

item.title: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter Makes Surprise Visit to Iraq
item.description: Mr. Carter arrived as American and Iraqi officials finished plans for an assault to retake Ramadi, a pivotal city west of Baghdad, from the Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Israel, Don’t Level My Village
item.description: Support grows for a Palestinian community under threat.
item.dc:creator: NASSER NAWAJA
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian child in the village of Susiya on the West Bank.

item.title: Greece Approves Second Set of Changes Needed for Bailout
item.description: Parliament approved a package of financial and judicial changes to keep negotiations on track for the bailout of about $94 billion.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Alexis Tsipras with Panos Skourletis, the energy minister, at a parliamentary session in Athens.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Turmoil in China’s Stock Markets Takes a Psychic Toll
item.description: Amid the recent turbulence in China’s stock markets, doctors have reported a surge in what they are calling “stock market anxiety syndrome.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investors following the ups and downs of the stock markets at a brokerage house in Beijing.

item.title: Greece Clears Final Reform Hurdle Before New Bailout Talks
item.description: Parliament overwhelmingly approved a new batch of reforms demanded by the country’s international creditors, clearing the way for talks on a third bailout.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Explosions Kill at Least 26
item.description: No one immediately claimed responsibility for the two attacks.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Kenya Trip Takes Obama Back to a Complex Part of Himself
item.description: How Kenya fits into Barack Obama’s identity remains one of the enduring questions of his presidency.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Barack Obama with his step-grandmother, known as Mama Sarah, as he returned to his ancestral rural village in Kenya in August 2006.

item.title: Campaign for Congressional Backing of Iran Nuclear Deal Begins
item.description: Israel’s ambassador to the United States met with the most conservative House Republicans to urge them to “leave everything on the field” to derail the accord.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center, and Ernest J. Moniz, left, before a classified briefing Wednesday with House members in Washington.
